bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 4, 1875

div1.p: Reed professes his love to Emilie Lawrence, and looks forward to seeing her again.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 4, 1875
div1.p:
At Boykins,
& away from Murfreesboro,
and my little E.! Well, at first thought,
this seems very hard to bear, but
when I consider the matter in
its truer light, I can but thank
a kind Father that I am permitted
occassionally to visit my own
little darling. If I don't stay
long, yet how it rejoices me
when I realize that my time
is so happily spent- Ah! my
love, you can't imagine how it
gladdens my heart & brightens
my Future to see your affec-
tion, & appreciation of poor
unworthy me- How it lifts
womanhood to a higher plane
than I had ever given it!
And gives me a faint vision
of the happiness and con-
tentment that is in store for
me- Seeking so clearly how de-
voted & loving a wife you
will be & knowing how fond
& kind a husband I shall
be, I have nothing to fear, but
can contemplate the coming
years with perfect calmness
of mind- Yes, more than this,
I can & do bids the days f
fly with lightning speed
till they bring my Emilie,
my love, my life to my Side!
Though it grieves me, more than
I can tell you, to part with
you, yet when I think of the
reunion with my own Emilie,
in a few short months, the
clouds begin to break away
& I can see a faint line of
light along the horizon-
Till we do meet again, my pre-
cious, you name will be ever
on my lips & your image in
my heart of hearts-!
Pardon this lead pencil scratch,
as I could not manage the
ink -- will write you, to-
night, darling.

Goodbye, my love, -- oh! think
of me often- & may the God
who has watched over you &
your happiness, thus far,
still keep you closely under
the shadow of His Almighty
Wing! Again, goodbye, my
own sweet Emilie-
